title-group.article-title: Effects of immersion and sustained bending on water absorption and thermomechanical properties of ultraviolet cured glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer composites

article-meta.aff: School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin, China

author-notes.corresp: Guijun Xian, School of Civil Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology, Harbin 150090, China. Email: gjxian@hit.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: An ultraviolet cured glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer composite can be cured in several 10 sec, which is potentially used for quick repair of concrete structures. In the present paper, combined effects of water or alkaline solution immersion and sustained bending on its water absorption and thermomechanical properties were investigated. With increasing the sustained bending levels, water uptake and diffusion rate monotonically increased in ultraviolet cured glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer. The combined effects lead to remarkable decreases in the tensile properties. More serious degradation of the tensile strength was found in the cases of higher sustained bending levels and/or alkaline solution immersion. After removal of sustained bending, residual deformation of samples was observed and depended on the bending levels and immersion medium, attributed to the orientation of the resin molecules. In all, 1% of water uptake led to about 8–9℃ reduction in the glass transition temperatures, regardless of sustained bending or immersion medium. The height of tan delta decrease with sustained bending levels indicates the occurrence of fiber debonding or delamination.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Compared to traditional civil engineering materials (i.e., steel and concrete), fiber-reinforced polymer (FRP) composites possess many irreplaceable advantages in terms of light weight, high strength, excellent corrosive resistance, ease of installation, etc.1 In recent years, FRP composites have been found to have fast increasing application in civil engineering, especially in the field of infrastructure rehabilitation, repair and upgrading.2–4 The long-term durability of FRPs in harsh civil engineering environments, however, has not been well understood, which adversely affects their safe, economic and wide application.5 Up to date, a number of researching works have been conducted on the durability of various FRPs in a range of environments, such as humidity, immersion in various solutions, temperatures and static or dynamic stresses.6,7 Most of the durability of FRPs were focused on a single environment, which is obviously apart from the real situations of FRPs in practice. FRPs applied in strengthening civil engineering structures, in many cases (such as concrete beam strengthening), have to face combined effects of sustained stress and various environments of immersion, temperatures etc. The combined effects on the long-term performance of FRPs as well as FRP-strengthened structures have already been considered as a critical topic for the application FRPs in civil engineering.8–11

By now, a few researchers have already conducted durability work of FRPs under combined stress/strain together with various environments. Helbling and Karbhari9 studied water sorption and tensile performance of a unidirectional pultruded E-glass/vinylester composite subjected to synergistic hygrothermal exposure and sustained bending. The sustained strain shows an accelerative effect on both water uptake and the degradation of tensile performance. The matrix cracking and fiber-matrix debonding are attributed to the more water uptake as well as the degradation in tensile strength.8 The sustained strain around 35.9% showed a transition in degradative response of a GFRP composite.8 The effect of tap water and sea water immersion on the long-term behavior of GFRP bars in concrete beams subjected to sustained loads were investigated, and a significant loss in strength was found. Laoubi et al. studied the effect of freeze-thaw cycling and sustained bending on GFRP strengthened concrete beams and found that no obvious degradation occurred for the beams.11

In the current paper, a UV curable GFRP composite (UV-GFRP) were developed for fast repair of concrete structures, which can be cured in several 10 sec and possesses a comparable mechanical properties with conventional ambient cured epoxy based GFRPs. UV-GFRP system used to strengthen existing structures have also been explored by some researchers.12,13 However, to author’s best knowledge, no work has been conducted on the durability of such novel systems yet.

In this paper, water uptake, long-term tensile properties as well as viscoelastic performance of the GFRP under combined water/alkaline solution immersion and sustained bending were investigated. The work aims to reveal the degradation mechanisms of the system, which will be meaningful for application of UV-GFRP in civil engineering and modification of current UV-GFRP systems.

sec.title: Sample preparation
sec.p: A UV-curable resin system, developed in the Lab for FRP Composite and Structure (Harbin Institute of Technology, China), is a mixture of Bisphenol A epoxy acrylate, polyester acrylate and diluent of TPGDA (CH2=CHO(OC3H6)3OCOCH=CH2) monomer. Photoinitiator is 2-hydroxy-2-methylpropiophenone, bought from CAC Group Co., Ltd of China. The viscosity of the resin with 2 wt.% initiatior at 25℃ is about 4000 mPa.S. Unidirectional glass fabric was kindly offered by Fyfe Co., ltd (San Diego, USA,) with the brand name of SEH 51A.

A UV lamp was bought from Xinlan Electric Light Source Co, Ltd (Henan, China) to cure the UV systems. The UV lamp gives the UV light with the wavelength of 365 nm, 1000 W and the UV intensity is 80 W/cm2.

UV curable resins with 2 wt.% of photo-initiator were mixed with hands for at least 5 min. The mixture was then used to saturate a layer of glass fabric with a hand layup process, and then cured with the UV lamp. With the UV lamp, the saturated one layer of glass fabric can be fully cured in 25 s, and the resulted glass transition temperature is 58℃, and the tensile strength, modulus and strain at break are 484 MPa, 27.1 GPa and 1.94%, respectively.
The nominal thickness of the fabricated GFRP plate is set as 1.3 mm, and the fiber content is 47.9 wt.% measured with the burn off testing method.

sec.title: Durability testing
sec.p:
The cured GFRP sample coupons were cut into strips in fiber direction with the dimensions of 250 mm × 10 mm × 1.3 mm. Metal fixtures (Figure 1) were set up to impose the strip of bending deformation, according to the three-point bending testing fixture. The imposed strain was adjusted with the position of the middle rod, made of stainless steel. In the present work, two strain levels were adopted. One is 25% of its ultimate strain (0.485%) and the other is 40% of its ultimate strain (0.776%). Figure 1.
Photograph of the bending fixture for ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) strip.

One set of samples were exposed to ambient air in laboratory for control samples (∼50% in humidity). The other two were immersed in distilled water or in alkaline solution (simulated concrete pore water with pH value of 12.5) at 25℃. The alkaline solution was made according to ACI 3 R-04 (Guide test methods for fiber-reinforced polymers (FRPs) for reinforcing or strengthening concrete structures). The alkaline solution consists of 118.5 g of Ca(OH)2, 0.9 g of NaOH and 4.2 g of KOH per 1 liter of distilled water.
The water uptake, residual deformation, tensile properties and glass transition temperatures of the samples were tracked in 6 months.

For water uptake, samples taken out of the baths were swiped off the surface water using tissue paper and weighted using an electronic balance with an accuracy of 0.01 mg. The presented data are an average for five coupons.

Tensile properties of the unidirectional UV-GFRPs were tested according to ASTM D 3039 with a tensile speed of 5 mm/min. For each condition, five samples were repeated and the average results were reported.

Aged UV-GFRP samples (50 × 10 × 1.3 mm3) cut from the middle part of the aged sample in fiber direction were used for Dynamic mechanical themal analysis (DMTA) test at a frequency of 1 Hz, a strain of 0.025% and a heating rate of 5℃ from 25 to 160℃ in three-point bending mode using an EXSTAR DMS6100 dynamic mechanical thermal analyzer (produced by SII NanoTechnology Inc, Japan).

sec.title: Effect of sustained bending on the water uptake of UV–GFRP strips
sec.p:
Water uptake curves of UV-GFRP strips immersed in water or alkaline solution under sustained bending with 0 (free sample), 25% and 40% of the ultimate strain are presented in Figure 2. As found, all water uptake curves (Figure 2(a) and (b)) follow the classic Fick’s law: the water uptake initially linearly increasing and then leveling off with square root of immersion time.6 The diffusion parameters for each case were determined with the curve fitting method with the Fickian equation, as shown in Reference [7]: (1)Da=π16 (hM∞ )2 (dMdt1/2 )2 where Da is the apparent coefficient of diffusion, h is the thickness of the specimens, t is the exposure time and M∞ is the saturation water uptake. The dot lines in Figure 2(a) and (b) represent the curve fitting curves with equation (1), which are almost perfect in line with the tested data points. The determined M∞ and Da are summarized in Tables 1 and 2 for both immersion cases. Mmax in the second rows of the tables represent the maximum water uptake content of the UV-GFRP samples in various conditions, directly read from the water uptake curves in Figure 2. The rate of diffusion (k) was calculated from M∞ and Da, supposing one-dimensional diffusion with the following equation:14 (2)Da=π(k/4M∞)2
Figure 2.
Water uptake curves of the ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) specimens immersed in water (a) or alkaline solutions (b) under different bending strain. The dot lines represent curve fitting with the Fickian model.
Table 1.
Equilibrium water uptake (M∞) and coefficient of diffusion (Da) for UV–GFRP specimens immersed in water
Bending strain level M∞ (%) Da (10–7 mm2/s) k (10–6 mm/s1/2)
0 0.77 0.49 3.85
25% 1.17 0.38 5.15
40% 1.36 0.92 9.31
UV: ultraviolet; GFRP: glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer.
Table 2.
Equilibrium water uptake (M∞) and coefficient of diffusion (Da) for UV–GFRP specimens immersed in alkaline solution
Bending strain level M∞ (%) Da (10–7 mm2/s) k (10–6 mm/s1/2)
0 0.74 0.33 3.03
25% 1.04 0.38 4.58
40% 1.15 0.75 7.11
UV: ultraviolet; GFRP: glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer.
The calculated k were also summarized in Tables 1 and 2.

As shown in Table 1, the imposed bending strain brings in much more water uptake, the higher the sustained bending, the higher the absorbed water content. For the rate of diffusion, the same trend is found. Similar results were reported on a pultruded vinyl ester-based GFRP composite.8,9 For the apparent coefficient of diffusion (Da) in both cases of immersion, however, there is no such monotonic trend (Tables 1 and 2). A very slight change in Da occurred when the sustained bending increased from 0 to 25%, while a dramatic increase in Da was realized as the sustained bending continuously increased by 40%. The variation of water uptake parameters (see in Tables 1 and 2) was attributed to the change of water absorption mechanisms under different sustained bending levels.

Two mechanisms of water uptake in a fiber-reinforced composite were expected.15,16 One is related to free volume of the polymer matrix, and the other is related to the defects in the composites, e.g., voids and debonding of fibers from the polymer resin (leading to the wicking effect).17 For the mechanisms with the free volume, the external tension stress will lead the free volume to increase, and thus the enhanced water diffusion coefficient and water uptake.8,15,16 On the contrary, the compression decreases the volume content of the system, bringing in reduced water diffusion coefficient and water uptake. For the mechanisms with defeats inside of the system, the water flow and storage in the microcraks as well as the interfaces between debonded fiber and matrix can bring in much remarkable water uptake, diffusion rate.17 For the present UV-GFRP system, the ultimate strain is around 1.94%, and the imposed tensile strain on the tension side only about 0.485% to 0.776%. Therefore, the macro-cracks of the UV-GFRP will not occur for both strain levels. As observed with light microscopy, even after 4 months of immersion, no cracks were found on the tension side of the UV-GFRP samples. Accordingly, under lower bending strain level (less than 25%), the free volume change due to the bending strain is dominant on the water absorption. However, under high bending strain (i.e., 40%), fiber debonding and the central delamination of the sample may occur, and a new path of water diffusion and new place for water uptake were realized. The wicking effect is dominant, leading to much higher water uptake and diffusion. The similar mechanisms of water absorption due to sustained bending were proposed elsewhere.9,8

It is noted as a point of interest that the UV-GFRPs immersed in water possess higher E∞, Da and k values than those immersed in alkaline solution under the same strain levels. This can be attributed to hydrolysis of UV-cured acrylate resin catalyzed by alkaline solution, which leads to continuous mass loss and offset the water uptake and diffusion. In one our previous study, the hydrolysis of the UV cured acrylate resin was reported.18 It is worth noting that the conventionally cured GFRP composites used for rehabilitation, upgrading of civil structures are based on epoxy resin system. The molecular structures of the cured epoxy resin system are mainly ether bonds, which is much stable than acrylate bonds of UV curing system during immersion. In view of this, it is not surprising that the UV-GFRP system exhibits less durable than conventional cured GFRP composites, especially during immersion.

sec.title: Effect of sustained bending and immersion on the tensile properties
sec.p:
Figure 3 shows the variation of tensile properties of UV-GFRP strips as a function of ageing time under combined effects of sustained bending and distilled water immersion. For comparison, samples under sustained bending in ambient were also tested and presented in Figure 3. In ambient conditions, the tensile strength gradually reduced by 7.9% and 16.9% with sustained bending strain of 25% and 40% in 6 months. While in distilled water, more degradation in the tensile strength is observed (Figure 3). The reduction is about 9.6% for the sustained bending strain of 25%, and 26.2% for the sustained bending strain of 40%. Clearly, combined with water immersion, the sustained strain exhibits a more detrimental effect on the degradation of the tensile strength. Compared to the water immersion, the alkaline solution immersion accelerates degradation in the strength of the UV-GFRP samples under sustained bending (Figure 4(a)), significantly. In 6 months, the tensile strength readily decreased by 41% under 25% of bending strain, and by 48.7% under 40% of bending strain when UV-GFRPs were immersed in alkaline solution. It is worth noting that the reduction in the tensile strength of a glass fiber reinforced vinyl ester pultruded strips is around 20–26% under the similar bending conditions for a similar water immersion.8 Figure 3.
Variations of tensile strength (a), modulus (b), and elongation at break (c) of ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) samples subjected to distilled water immersion and sustained bending or only sustained bending.
Figure 4.
Variations of tensile strength (a), modulus (b) and elongation at break (c) of ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) samples subjected to combined alkaline solution immersion and sustained bending or only sustained bending.

Figure 3(c) shows the variation of the ultimate tensile strain as a function of ageing time. As shown, the ultimate strain gradually decreases with the ageing time by 13–17%, and immersion in water does not bring more degradation. The higher the sustained bending strain leads to the higher reduction in the ultimate strain. More severe degradations of the ultimate strain were found for the combined effect of sustained bending and alkaline solutions (Figure 4(c)). This trend is consistent with the change of the tensile strength.

As mentioned in the section of water absorption, the combined effects of sustained bending and immersion may bring in fiber debonding, cracks in resin as well as delamination, which undoubtedly can cause the premature breaks of UV-GFRPs during tension, resulting in decreased tensile strength and ultimate strain. Since alkaline immersion additionally leads to hydrolysis of the resin, more severe degradations in the strength and ultimate strain were realized.

As opposed to the tensile strength and the ultimate elongation, the tensile modulus was increased by 12% for the samples under sustained bending in ambient conditions (Figure 3(b)) regardless of the level of the sustained strain. Combined with the water immersion, the tensile modulus is enhanced to a similar extent for the lower sustained bending. However, under the higher sustained bending combined with distilled water, the tensile modulus exhibits much less affected. Similarly, UV-GFRPs subjected to combined sustained bending and alkaline solution exhibit clearly increases in the tensile modulus, even under high sustained bending level (Figure 4(b)). Orientation of the resins due to the sustained tension strain on the tension side of the UV-GFRP samples, as expected, can contribute to the enhanced modulus. In addition, due to the extraction of un-cured small molecules during immersion, the resin system will be hardening. This will also lead to the increase of the modulus.

sec.title: Residual strain
sec.p: As assumed above, the orientation of resin molecules due to extended bending strain occurred and was responsible for the increased tensile modulus. On the other side, when the imposed bending strain was removed, the oriented resin molecules will cause residual flexural deformation. In this section, the residual flexural deformation is discussed.

The residual strain of UV-GFRPs is calculated by the flexural deformation (s), which was directly measured on the specimens immediately after they were taken off from the fixture. The residual strain is expressed as: (3)ɛ=(6sh)/l2 where, h is the thickness of the sample, and l is the span length of the specimen.

Variation of the residual strain as a function of ageing time under various sustained bending strains and immersion conditions is shown in Figure 5. As found, for both ambient and immersion cases, the sustained bending levels exhibit a significant effect on the residual strains. Even only after 1 week under sustained bending, the residual strain in immersion or ambient environments, the residual strain is in the range of 0.04–0.05% for 25% ultimate strain and ∼0.13% for 40% ultimate strain. With the ageing time extending, the residual strain gradually increase with different rates, dependent on the exposure conditions. The specimens immersed in alkaline solution possess the highest residual strain, while the specimens in water and ambient conditions have the middle or lowest residual strain, respectively. After 6 months, the maximum residual strain reaches 0.34% for specimens imposed with 40% ultimate strain and immersed in alkaline solution. Figure 5.
Residual strains due to sustained bending in various environments.

Such high residual strain is attributed to the orientation of the resin matrix due to the long-term sustained deformation. The absorbed water molecules will plasticize the resin system and facilitate the orientation process. Therefore, the higher residual strains are formed for the samples under the combined effects (Figure 5).

As mentioned above, the orientation of the resin molecules due to sustained bending and extraction of uncured small molecules resulted in the improvement of tensile modulus (Figures 3(b) and 4(b)) and the residual strain (Figure 5). Therefore, it is interesting to plot the curves of the tensile modulus vs. the residual strain, which are presented in Figure 6. As shown, for both bending levels, the tensile modulus increases with the residual strain. This result support the assumption that the increase of the modulus with ageing time (Figures 3(b) and 4(b)) is mainly coming from orientation of the resin molecules. Figure 6.
Tensile modules as a function of variation of residual strain. (a) Under sustained bending strain of 25% and (b) under sustained bending strain of 40%.

Compared to ambient aged UV-GFRP, the larger residual strain leads to relative lower modulus increase (Figure 6(a) and (b)), which is attributed to the offsetting effects from water plasticizing on the modulus increase. As shown in Figure 6(a) and (b), the residual stress under higher sustained bending levels (Figure 6(b)) shows a reduced effect on the improvement of tensile modulus. As expected, the permanent damages (e.g., delanination and debonding of fibers) that may have occurred under high sustained bending leads to extra residual strain, which will not contribute to the increase of the tensile modulus.

sec.title: Viscoelastic performance
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows tan delta curves of various UV-GFRP specimens subjected to sustained bending (Figure 7(a)) in ambient, or combined with immersion in water (Figure 7(b)) or alkaline solutions (Figure 7(c)) for 6 months. Tgs determined by the tan delta peaks as well as the height of tan delta peaks are summarized in Figure 8(a). As shown, water/alkaline immersion (samples without sustained bending) leads to remarkable reduction in the glass transition temperatures (Tg). Compared to control samples, Tg decreased by 6℃ for samples immersed in alkaline solution and ∼8℃ for samples immersed in water for 6 months, respectively. Additional sustained bending brings in further reduction in Tg by 2–3℃ (Figure 8(a)). The Tg reduction is attributed to the plasticizing effect of the absorbed water. Sustained bending brings more water uptakes, being responsible for the lower Tgs. Figure 7.
Tan delta curves of specimens exposed to ambient (a), water immersion (b) and alkaline solution immersion (c) for 6 months. The control specimens were just cured and not aged.
Figure 8.
Glass transition temperatures (a) and height of tan delta peak (b) of ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) samples subject to sustained bending and water/alkaline solution immersion for 6 months.

Figure 9 shows the variation of the glass transition temperatures of UV GFRP as a function of water uptake content. As shown, the variation of Tg initially shows a reduction linearly with water content and then levels off. Note, the final data points for two curves are related to 40% bending deformation (see in Tables 1 and 2). As mentioned above, the high sustained deformation (i.e., 40% of ultimate strain) may bring in resin cracks, debonding of fibers as well as de-lamination, which bring in extra water uptake in those defects. Only the water molecules that swells in resin molecules and brings in more free volume8 can plasticize the resin system. Such water existing in macro-defects will not plasticize the resin. Based on this assumption, remove the final two data for water and alkaline solution, and the effect of water uptake content on the depression of Tg is determined by linearity fitting method. With 1% water uptake, Tg is reduced by 8.75℃ for distilled water immersion and 8.60℃ for alkaline immersion. There is no much difference for two cases. Figure 9.
Variation of glass transition of ultraviolet (UV)–glass fiber-reinforced acylate polymer (GFRP) under combined effect of sustained bending and water/alkaline solution immersion for 6 months as a function of the content of water uptake (see Tables 1 and 2).

The height of the tan delta peak represents the viscoelastic level of a composite system,7,19 which are summarized in Figure 8(b). For the control samples or samples under lower sustained bending, the heights of tan delta peaks change very slightly, in the range of 0.2 to 0.23. However, when the samples were subjected to 40% sustained bending strain and immersion, the height of the tan delta peak reduced by 0.17. The reduction of the height of the tan delta peak for samples under combined effects of sustained force and immersion is ascribed to debonding of fibers as well as the resin cracks.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In the present paper, effect of combined water/alkaline immersion and sustained bending on the degradation of a UV-cured GFRP composite was investigated, in terms of water uptake, tensile properties, residual deformation and viscoelastic performances. The following conclusions were drawn according to the study.
Sustained bending accelerates the diffusion rate and increases the water uptake remarkably, the higher the bending strain, the more water absorbed and the higher the diffusion rate.
Under combined alkaline solution immersion and sustained bending, the tensile strength of the UV-GFRP decreased remarkably with ageing time and sustained bending levels, while the tensile modulus increased slightly. For the case of water immersion, a similar trend was found but to a much lower extent.
Water/alkaline solution immersion and sustained bending show a synergistic effect on the residual deformation for aged UV-GFRP strips. The higher the residual strain is correlated to the higher level of the molecular orientation and thus the higher the tensile modulus.
A total of 1% water uptake brings in Tg reduction by ∼8.6 to 8.75℃; High sustained bending level may bring in severe fiber debonding and delamination, and thus decreases the height of tan delta.

sec.p: None declared.
